defs.docs: Coloring terminal so simple, you already know how to do it !

attributes.value: /Coloring terminal so simple, you already know how to do it !
/    "or clear things up. This is default color and style".red().bold().clear();
/    format!("{:30}", "format works as expected. This will be padded".blue());
/    format!("{:.3}", "and this will be green but truncated to 3 chars".green());
/ See [the `Colorize` trait](./trait.Colorize.html) for all the methods.

defs.name: Color
defs.value:
pub enum Color {
    Black,
    Red,
    Green,
    Yellow,
    Blue,
    Magenta,
    Cyan,
    White,
    BrightBlack,
    BrightRed,
    BrightGreen,
    BrightYellow,
    BrightBlue,
    BrightMagenta,
    BrightCyan,
    BrightWhite,
}
defs.docs: The 8 standard colors.

defs.name: control
defs.docs: A couple of functions to enable and disable coloring.

attributes.value: / A couple of functions to enable and disable coloring.

defs.name: set_virtual_terminal
defs.docs: Sets a flag to the console to use a virtual terminal environment.

attributes.value: / Sets a flag to the console to use a virtual terminal environment.
/ This is primarily used for Windows 10 environments which will not correctly colorize
/ the outputs based on ANSI escape codes.
/ The returned `Result` is _always_ `Ok(())`, the return type was kept to ensure backwards
/ println!("{}", "bright cyan".bright_cyan());	// will print '[96mbright cyan[0m' on windows 10

defs.name: ShouldColorize
defs.docs: A flag to to if coloring should occur.

attributes.value: / A flag to to if coloring should occur.

defs.name: set_override
defs.docs:
Use this to force colored to ignore the environment and always/never colorize
 See example/control.rs

attributes.value: / Use this to force colored to ignore the environment and always/never colorize

defs.name: unset_override
defs.docs:
Remove the manual override and let the environment decide if it's ok to colorize
 See example/control.rs

attributes.value: / Remove the manual override and let the environment decide if it's ok to colorize

defs.name: SHOULD_COLORIZE
defs.docs: The persistent [`ShouldColorize`].

defs.name: from_env
defs.docs:
Reads environment variables and checks if output is a tty to determine
 whether colorization should be used or not.
 `CLICOLOR_FORCE` takes highest priority, followed by `NO_COLOR`,
 followed by `CLICOLOR` combined with tty check.

attributes.value: / Reads environment variables and checks if output is a tty to determine
/ whether colorization should be used or not.
/ followed by `CLICOLOR` combined with tty check.

defs.name: should_colorize
defs.docs: Returns if the current coloring is expected.

attributes.value: / Returns if the current coloring is expected.

defs.name: Style
defs.docs: A combinatorial style such as bold, italics, dimmed, etc.

attributes.value: / A combinatorial style such as bold, italics, dimmed, etc.

defs.name: Styles
defs.value:
pub enum Styles {
    Clear,
    Bold,
    Dimmed,
    Underline,
    Reversed,
    Italic,
    Blink,
    Hidden,
    Strikethrough,
}

defs.name: contains
defs.docs: Check if the current style has one of [`Styles`](Styles) switched on.

attributes.value: / Check if the current style has one of [`Styles`](Styles) switched on.

defs.name: ColoredString
defs.docs: A string that may have color and/or style applied to it.

attributes.value: / A string that may have color and/or style applied to it.

defs.name: Colorize
defs.docs: The trait that enables something to be given color.

attributes.value: / The trait that enables something to be given color.
/ You can use `colored` effectively simply by importing this trait
/ and then using its methods on `String` and `&str`.
